docs.abstract: Editorial welcomes Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report finding that the obesity rate among preschoolers from poor families has fallen in 19 states and American territories, and has risen in only three states; contends that report is an encouraging sign in fight to control childhood obesity, but cautions that there is still much room for improvement in addressing obesity epidemic.
docs.lead_paragraph: An encouraging report suggests that the tide could finally be turning in this important battle.
docs.snippet: An encouraging report suggests that the tide could finally be turning in this important battle.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

headline.print_headline: Poor Children Show a Decline In Obesity Rate
headline.main: Poor Children Show a Decline in Obesity Rate

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention releases report that shows a consistent pattern of decline in obesity rates among low-income children; cause of decline remains a mystery, but researchers offer theories that include an increase in breast-feeding, drop in calories from sugary drinks and changes in food offered in federal nutrition programs for women and children.
docs.lead_paragraph: A new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is the first major government report to show a consistent pattern of decline for low-income children.
docs.snippet: A new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is the first major government report to show a consistent pattern of decline for low-income children.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.abstract: Food policy can make us healthy or it can make us sick.
docs.snippet: Food policy can make us healthy or it can make us sick.
